Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Zero-power Wireless Flame Detector for Ubiquitous Fire Monitoring
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a flame detection technology that consumes near zero power in standby mode, hence enabling the implementation of wireless fire sensor networks with greatly reduced cost for ubiquitous fire monitoring. A flame detector can often respond more accurately and faster than a smoke or heat detector, since its targeting indicator is more exclusive to fires and it does not experience the delayed detection time. The drawbacks of existing flame detector technologies include high power consumption, high manufacturing cost, and bulky form factor. These drawbacks prevent current flame detectors from being widely adopted in the market. Instead, the proposed miniaturized battery-powered wireless flame detectors may last up to 10 years without charging and be easily retrofitted to address multiple deployment needs. The new detectors may provide a primary safety measure for fire monitoring in broader commercial market sectors such as construction sites, waste facilities, warehouses and forests. The project may have an immediate impact on the disruptive fire-related accidents such as 2019-20 Australian bushfire and Notre Dame Cathedral fire, saving hundreds of lives and preventing billions of dollars in asset losses worldwide.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of micromechanical flame detectors that consume near-zero power in standby mode until awakened by the specific infrared signature emitted by a flame. Currently, no existing technology could enable the implementation of large-scale wireless fire sensor networks due to the prohibitive cost associated with ownership, installation and maintenance. The fundamental technical challenge lies in the continuous power consumption of state-of-the-art sensor technologies. Commercially available sensors rely on active electronics to detect and discriminate signals of interest. Therefore, current flame detectors consume power continuously to monitor the environment even when there is no relevant data to be detected, which results in a short battery lifetime (a few months). The proposed flame detector relies on the recently developed, zero-power digitizing infrared sensors that can selectively harvest the energy from specific infrared signatures emitted from a warm object to operate without using any electrical power. The fire sensor market requires products to have certificated performance and to meet different standards and regulations. The goal of is to pinpoint customersâ€™ needs and develop a commercialization path to deliver products meeting all requirements for a beachhead market.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Title:

I-Corps: Zero-power Wireless Flame Detector for Ubiquitous Fire Monitoring

PD/PI Name:

Matteo Rinaldi, Principal Investigator

Recipient Organization:

Northeastern University

 

Recent advances in infrared (IR) detection technologies have led to the invention of a new class of IR sensors, called zero-power IR digitizing sensors that are sleep yet always alert. Compared to conventional IR sensors, their standby power consumption is orders of magnitude lower, yet packed with on par performance in an even smaller footprint. Such a new capability has numerous merits to many internet-ofthings applications such as environmental monitoring and occupancy sensing. In particular, before the project, our team has noticed a growing demand in the fire safety industry in which wireless fire detection sensors with a high sensor granularity are desirable in locations that face substantial fire risks but lack the access to consistent electrical power. The said new IR sensing technology can also be beneficial to the home automation industry by extending battery lifetime and reducing device size. During the customer discovery process in the NSF I-Corps program, our team has conducted more than 100 customer interviews to identify the best product market fit for the technology. In particular, the team has come up with a number of business hypotheses for both fire safety and occupancy sensing market sectors and validated critical value propositions for specific customer segments through the customer interview process. Some of the key customers we have interviewed include state fire marshals, risk engineers, business consultants, product managers, chief technical officers, and product engineers.

 

In the initial stage of customer discovery process, our team has discovered that there are stringent regulations and codes imposed on the new and emerging fire safety related products. The implementation of new fire safety codes and product listing can be extremely time consuming and is generally to be avoided for a new technology entering a new market. Instead, the team has identified a clear need in the current smart home market: the state-of-the-art human detectors (namely, the passive infrared (PIR) sensors) suffer from (1) a high false alarm rate and (2) the complex design and engineering process. Some common false alarms include the failure to detect presence of human when there is no movement, or being falsely triggered due to moving vehicles, falling branches, or pets. Such high false alarm rate is inherently present in the PIR-enabled human sensing due to the reliance on detection motion of a warm object and to the noise produced by their photosensitive elements. Furthermore, the PIR technologies must rely on the use of Fresnel lens, which results in additional complex design and engineering processes. In addition to the apparent pain points associated with the PIR-based human detection technologies, the reduction in sensor cost has been identified as one of the crucial requirements for a new sensor technology during the customer discovery process.

 

The I-Corps project has not only helped develop a clear business thesis for the proposed technology, but also has instilled in the team the methodology of finding a product market fit through an extensive customer discovery process. Furthermore, the program has helped build a strong foundation for the paths forward to a commercialization such as the verification of value propositions and developing a business model to be reviewed by potential investors. The team also plans to continue to conduct more customer interviews to verify a set of hypotheses for the applications beyond the market sectors explored during the NSF I-Corps program, such as the smart agriculture, commercial personal electronics and fire safety in the industrial facilities.
